newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Euro Parliament rejects urgent beef review.
newsitem.headline: Euro Parliament rejects urgent beef review.

text.p: The European Parliament voted overwhelmingly on Wednesday to reject a request by European Union farm ministers to examine proposals urgently to reform the beef sector.
"We only got the urgency procedure call yesterday," said Christian Jacob, the French chairman of the parliament's agriculture committee.
The Parliament had been asked to give its opinion so that a decision could be taken by EU farm ministers at their next meeting on September 16-17.
But it would have meant the Parliament giving a view in 24 hours as its current mini-session in Brussels ends on Thursday.
Instead the Parliament asked the EU Farm Council to make a fresh request and sub-divide it into three parts.
It did not specify the parts.
The European Commission proposed on July 30 a series of measures to reduce beef production to help avoid a build-up of surpluses as consumers shun beef due to the mad cow crisis.

Young male cattle of between seven and nine months would be eligible for intervention storage, 1996 and 1997 intervention tonnage ceilings raised and ceilings on the number of male cattle receiving the special beef premium reduced.
A calf slaughter scheme in Britain and Portugal would be extended to all member states and greater incentives offered for extensive beef production.
